snippet: Lithium-ion batteries are popular because they are powerful and charge quickly, but Boeing has had serious problems with the technology on its new Dreamliner.
abstract: Federal investigators are trying to determine why powerful and lightweight lithium-ion batteries caught fire in Boeing's long-awaited 787 Dreamliner, and have grounded plane until they figure it out; while passengers were not deemed at risk, there remain serious concerns about prospect that battery failure could have catastrophic results in future.

byline.original: By JAD MOUAWAD and CHRISTOPHER DREW
byline.contributor: Matthew L. Wald contributed reporting from Washington and Andrew Martin from New York.

lead_paragraph: Lithium-ion batteries are popular because they are powerful and charge quickly, but Boeing has had serious problems with the technology on its new Dreamliner.

headline.seo: Inside the 787, an Unsettling Risk for Boeing
headline.main: Praised but Fire-Prone, Battery Fails Test in 787
headline.print_headline: Praised but Fire-Prone, Battery Fails Test in 787
